abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Technical Assistance
            Project for Pakistan was satisfactory. The project achieved
            its main objectives, its impact has been substantial,
            sustainability is likely, and both the Bank and Borrower
            performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, there is a need to define
            precisely the composition and staffing level of the project
            implementation unit. Failure in having done so initially was
            a reason for delay in project implementation. Second, a
            balance should be maintained between pre-identified
            subprojects and unidentified projects. Pre-identification of
            subprojects allows for smoother and more rapid project
            execution. However, unallocated funds providing financing
            for subprojects that are identified as the Government
            proceeds with its structural adjustment program provide
            useful flexibility. An unallocated amount not exceeding 25
            to 30 percent of the credit amount would be desirable.
            Third, adoption and use of specific eligibility criteria for
            selecting projects is important to implement the project
            efficiently. Lastly, adequate Bank staff resources should be
            allocated to supervise the implementation of the project.
